name: language
title: Google Cloud Natural Language API
description: Google Cloud Natural Language API provides natural language understanding technologies to developers. Examples include sentiment analysis, entity recognition, and text annotations.

parameters.name: key
parameters.desc: API key. Your API key identifies your project and provides you with API access, quota, and reports. Required unless you provide an OAuth 2.0 token.

parameters.name: quotaUser
parameters.desc: Available to use for quota purposes for server-side applications. Can be any arbitrary string assigned to a user, but should not exceed 40 characters.

parameters.name: oauth_token
parameters.desc: OAuth 2.0 token for the current user.

parameters.name: prettyPrint
parameters.desc: Returns response with indentations and line breaks.

parameters.name: fields
parameters.desc: Selector specifying which fields to include in a partial response.

schemas.name: Sentiment
schemas.desc:
Represents the feeling associated with the entire text or entities in
the text.

fields.name: score
fields.desc:
Sentiment score between -1.0 (negative sentiment) and 1.0
(positive sentiment).

fields.name: magnitude
fields.desc:
A non-negative number in the [0, +inf) range, which represents
the absolute magnitude of sentiment regardless of score (positive or
negative).

fields.name: polarity
fields.desc:
DEPRECATED FIELD - This field is being deprecated in
favor of score. Please refer to our documentation at
https://cloud.google.com/natural-language/docs for more information.

schemas.name: PartOfSpeech
schemas.desc: Represents part of speech information for a token.

fields.name: voice
fields.desc: The grammatical voice.

enum.name: VOICE_UNKNOWN
enum.desc: Voice is not applicable in the analyzed language or is not predicted.

fields.name: mood
fields.desc: The grammatical mood.

enum.name: MOOD_UNKNOWN
enum.desc: Mood is not applicable in the analyzed language or is not predicted.

fields.name: tag
fields.desc: The part of speech tag.

fields.name: proper
fields.desc: The grammatical properness.

enum.name: PROPER_UNKNOWN
enum.desc: Proper is not applicable in the analyzed language or is not predicted.

fields.name: reciprocity
fields.desc: The grammatical reciprocity.

enum.name: RECIPROCITY_UNKNOWN
enum.desc:
Reciprocity is not applicable in the analyzed language or is not
predicted.

fields.name: tense
fields.desc: The grammatical tense.

enum.name: TENSE_UNKNOWN
enum.desc: Tense is not applicable in the analyzed language or is not predicted.

fields.name: form
fields.desc: The grammatical form.

enum.name: FORM_UNKNOWN
enum.desc: Form is not applicable in the analyzed language or is not predicted.

fields.name: number
fields.desc: The grammatical number.

enum.name: NUMBER_UNKNOWN
enum.desc: Number is not applicable in the analyzed language or is not predicted.

fields.name: aspect
fields.desc: The grammatical aspect.

enum.name: ASPECT_UNKNOWN
enum.desc: Aspect is not applicable in the analyzed language or is not predicted.

fields.name: gender
fields.desc: The grammatical gender.

enum.name: GENDER_UNKNOWN
enum.desc: Gender is not applicable in the analyzed language or is not predicted.

fields.name: person
fields.desc: The grammatical person.

enum.name: PERSON_UNKNOWN
enum.desc: Person is not applicable in the analyzed language or is not predicted.

fields.name: case
fields.desc: The grammatical case.

enum.name: CASE_UNKNOWN
enum.desc: Case is not applicable in the analyzed language or is not predicted.

schemas.name: AnnotateTextRequest
schemas.desc:
The request message for the text annotation API, which can perform multiple
analysis types (sentiment, entities, and syntax) in one call.

fields.name: features
fields.desc: The enabled features.

fields.name: encodingType
fields.desc: The encoding type used by the API to calculate offsets.

enum.name: NONE
enum.desc:
If `EncodingType` is not specified, encoding-dependent information (such as
`begin_offset`) will be set at `-1`.

enum.name: UTF8
enum.desc:
Encoding-dependent information (such as `begin_offset`) is calculated based
on the UTF-8 encoding of the input. C++ and Go are examples of languages
that use this encoding natively.

enum.name: UTF16
enum.desc:
Encoding-dependent information (such as `begin_offset`) is calculated based
on the UTF-16 encoding of the input. Java and Javascript are examples of
languages that use this encoding natively.

enum.name: UTF32
enum.desc:
Encoding-dependent information (such as `begin_offset`) is calculated based
on the UTF-32 encoding of the input. Python is an example of a language
that uses this encoding natively.

fields.name: document
fields.desc: Input document.

schemas.name: TextSpan
schemas.desc: Represents an output piece of text.

fields.name: beginOffset
fields.desc:
The API calculates the beginning offset of the content in the original
document according to the EncodingType specified in the API request.

fields.name: content
fields.desc: The content of the output text.

schemas.name: Sentence
schemas.desc: Represents a sentence in the input document.

fields.name: text
fields.desc: The sentence text.

fields.name: sentiment
fields.desc:
For calls to AnalyzeSentiment or if
AnnotateTextRequest.Features.extract_document_sentiment is set to
true, this field will contain the sentiment for the sentence.

fields.name: document
fields.desc: Input document.

fields.name: encodingType
fields.desc: The encoding type used by the API to calculate offsets.

enum.name: NONE
enum.desc:
If `EncodingType` is not specified, encoding-dependent information (such as
`begin_offset`) will be set at `-1`.

enum.name: UTF8
enum.desc:
Encoding-dependent information (such as `begin_offset`) is calculated based
on the UTF-8 encoding of the input. C++ and Go are examples of languages
that use this encoding natively.

enum.name: UTF16
enum.desc:
Encoding-dependent information (such as `begin_offset`) is calculated based
on the UTF-16 encoding of the input. Java and Javascript are examples of
languages that use this encoding natively.

enum.name: UTF32
enum.desc:
Encoding-dependent information (such as `begin_offset`) is calculated based
on the UTF-32 encoding of the input. Python is an example of a language
that uses this encoding natively.

fields.name: documentSentiment
fields.desc: The overall sentiment of the input document.

fields.name: language
fields.desc:
The language of the text, which will be the same as the language specified
in the request or, if not specified, the automatically-detected language.

fields.name: sentences
fields.desc: The sentiment for all the sentences in the document.

schemas.name: DependencyEdge
schemas.desc: Represents dependency parse tree information for a token.

fields.name: headTokenIndex
fields.desc:
Represents the head of this token in the dependency tree.
This is the index of the token which has an arc going to this token.
The index is the position of the token in the array of tokens returned
by the API method. If this token is a root token, then the
`head_token_index` is its own index.

fields.name: label
fields.desc: The parse label for the token.

enum.name: ATTR
enum.desc: Attribute dependent of a copular verb

enum.name: CCOMP
enum.desc: Clausal complement of a verb or adjective

enum.name: GOESWITH
enum.desc: Goes with (part of a word in a text not well edited)

enum.name: NPADVMOD
enum.desc: Noun phrase used as an adverbial modifier

enum.name: PCOMP
enum.desc: The complement of a preposition is a clause

enum.name: PRONL
enum.desc: The relationship between a verb and verbal morpheme

enum.name: SNUM
enum.desc: Suffix specifying a unit of number

enum.name: VMOD
enum.desc: Clause headed by an infinite form of the verb that modifies a noun

enum.name: LIST
enum.desc: List for chains of comparable items

schemas.name: Status
schemas.desc:
The `Status` type defines a logical error model that is suitable for different
programming environments, including REST APIs and RPC APIs. It is used by
[gRPC](https://github.com/grpc). The error model is designed to be:

- Simple to use and understand for most users
- Flexible enough to meet unexpected needs

# Overview

The `Status` message contains three pieces of data: error code, error message,
and error details. The error code should be an enum value of
google.rpc.Code, but it may accept additional error codes if needed.  The
error message should be a developer-facing English message that helps
developers *understand* and *resolve* the error. If a localized user-facing
error message is needed, put the localized message in the error details or
localize it in the client. The optional error details may contain arbitrary
information about the error. There is a predefined set of error detail types
in the package `google.rpc` which can be used for common error conditions.

# Language mapping

The `Status` message is the logical representation of the error model, but it
is not necessarily the actual wire format. When the `Status` message is
exposed in different client libraries and different wire protocols, it can be
mapped differently. For example, it will likely be mapped to some exceptions
in Java, but more likely mapped to some error codes in C.

# Other uses

The error model and the `Status` message can be used in a variety of
environments, either with or without APIs, to provide a
consistent developer experience across different environments.

Example uses of this error model include:

- Partial errors. If a service needs to return partial errors to the client,
    it may embed the `Status` in the normal response to indicate the partial
    errors.

- Workflow errors. A typical workflow has multiple steps. Each step may
    have a `Status` message for error reporting purpose.

- Batch operations. If a client uses batch request and batch response, the
    `Status` message should be used directly inside batch response, one for
    each error sub-response.

- Asynchronous operations. If an API call embeds asynchronous operation
    results in its response, the status of those operations should be
    represented directly using the `Status` message.

- Logging. If some API errors are stored in logs, the message `Status` could
    be used directly after any stripping needed for security/privacy reasons.

fields.name: details
fields.desc:
A list of messages that carry the error details.  There will be a
common set of message types for APIs to use.

fields.name: code
fields.desc: The status code, which should be an enum value of google.rpc.Code.

fields.name: message
fields.desc:
A developer-facing error message, which should be in English. Any
user-facing error message should be localized and sent in the
google.rpc.Status.details field, or localized by the client.

fields.name: type
fields.desc:
Required. If the type is not set or is `TYPE_UNSPECIFIED`,
returns an `INVALID_ARGUMENT` error.

enum.name: TYPE_UNSPECIFIED
enum.desc: The content type is not specified.

fields.name: content
fields.desc: The content of the input in string format.

fields.name: gcsContentUri
fields.desc:
The Google Cloud Storage URI where the file content is located.
This URI must be of the form: gs://bucket_name/object_name. For more
details, see https://cloud.google.com/storage/docs/reference-uris.
NOTE: Cloud Storage object versioning is not supported.

fields.name: language
fields.desc:
The language of the document (if not specified, the language is automatically detected). Both ISO and BCP-47 language codes are accepted.
**Current Language Restrictions:** * Only English, Spanish, and Japanese textual content are supported. If the language (either specified by the caller or automatically detected) is not supported by the called API method, an `INVALID_ARGUMENT` error is returned.

fields.name: encodingType
fields.desc: The encoding type used by the API to calculate offsets.

enum.name: NONE
enum.desc:
If `EncodingType` is not specified, encoding-dependent information (such as
`begin_offset`) will be set at `-1`.

enum.name: UTF8
enum.desc:
Encoding-dependent information (such as `begin_offset`) is calculated based
on the UTF-8 encoding of the input. C++ and Go are examples of languages
that use this encoding natively.

enum.name: UTF16
enum.desc:
Encoding-dependent information (such as `begin_offset`) is calculated based
on the UTF-16 encoding of the input. Java and Javascript are examples of
languages that use this encoding natively.

enum.name: UTF32
enum.desc:
Encoding-dependent information (such as `begin_offset`) is calculated based
on the UTF-32 encoding of the input. Python is an example of a language
that uses this encoding natively.

fields.name: document
fields.desc: Input document.

fields.name: encodingType
fields.desc:
The encoding type used by the API to calculate sentence offsets for the
sentence sentiment.

enum.name: NONE
enum.desc:
If `EncodingType` is not specified, encoding-dependent information (such as
`begin_offset`) will be set at `-1`.

enum.name: UTF8
enum.desc:
Encoding-dependent information (such as `begin_offset`) is calculated based
on the UTF-8 encoding of the input. C++ and Go are examples of languages
that use this encoding natively.

enum.name: UTF16
enum.desc:
Encoding-dependent information (such as `begin_offset`) is calculated based
on the UTF-16 encoding of the input. Java and Javascript are examples of
languages that use this encoding natively.

enum.name: UTF32
enum.desc:
Encoding-dependent information (such as `begin_offset`) is calculated based
on the UTF-32 encoding of the input. Python is an example of a language
that uses this encoding natively.

fields.name: document
fields.desc:
Input document. Currently, `analyzeSentiment` only supports English text
(Document.language="EN").

fields.name: entities
fields.desc: The recognized entities in the input document.

fields.name: language
fields.desc:
The language of the text, which will be the same as the language specified
in the request or, if not specified, the automatically-detected language.
See Document.language field for more details.

schemas.name: Entity
schemas.desc:
Represents a phrase in the text that is a known entity, such as
a person, an organization, or location. The API associates information, such
as salience and mentions, with entities.

fields.name: type
fields.desc: The entity type.

fields.name: metadata
fields.desc:
Metadata associated with the entity.

Currently, Wikipedia URLs and Knowledge Graph MIDs are provided, if
available. The associated keys are "wikipedia_url" and "mid", respectively.

fields.name: salience
fields.desc:
The salience score associated with the entity in the [0, 1.0] range.

The salience score for an entity provides information about the
importance or centrality of that entity to the entire document text.
Scores closer to 0 are less salient, while scores closer to 1.0 are highly
salient.

fields.name: mentions
fields.desc:
The mentions of this entity in the input document. The API currently
supports proper noun mentions.

fields.name: name
fields.desc: The representative name for the entity.

fields.name: language
fields.desc:
The language of the text, which will be the same as the language specified
in the request or, if not specified, the automatically-detected language.
See Document.language field for more details.

fields.name: sentences
fields.desc: Sentences in the input document.

fields.name: tokens
fields.desc: Tokens, along with their syntactic information, in the input document.

fields.name: documentSentiment
fields.desc:
The overall sentiment for the document. Populated if the user enables
AnnotateTextRequest.Features.extract_document_sentiment.

fields.name: language
fields.desc:
The language of the text, which will be the same as the language specified
in the request or, if not specified, the automatically-detected language.
See Document.language field for more details.

fields.name: sentences
fields.desc:
Sentences in the input document. Populated if the user enables
AnnotateTextRequest.Features.extract_syntax.

fields.name: tokens
fields.desc:
Tokens, along with their syntactic information, in the input document.
Populated if the user enables
AnnotateTextRequest.Features.extract_syntax.

fields.name: entities
fields.desc:
Entities, along with their semantic information, in the input document.
Populated if the user enables
AnnotateTextRequest.Features.extract_entities.

schemas.name: Token
schemas.desc: Represents the smallest syntactic building block of the text.

fields.name: partOfSpeech
fields.desc: Parts of speech tag for this token.

fields.name: text
fields.desc: The token text.

fields.name: dependencyEdge
fields.desc: Dependency tree parse for this token.

fields.name: lemma
fields.desc: [Lemma](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lemma_%28morphology%29) of the token.

schemas.name: EntityMention
schemas.desc:
Represents a mention for an entity in the text. Currently, proper noun
mentions are supported.

fields.name: type
fields.desc: The type of the entity mention.

fields.name: text
fields.desc: The mention text.

schemas.name: Features
schemas.desc:
All available features for sentiment, syntax, and semantic analysis.
Setting each one to true will enable that specific analysis for the input.

fields.name: extractDocumentSentiment
fields.desc: Extract document-level sentiment.

fields.name: extractEntities
fields.desc: Extract entities.

fields.name: extractSyntax
fields.desc: Extract syntax information.

methods.name: analyzeSyntax
methods.desc:
Analyzes the syntax of the text and provides sentence boundaries and
tokenization along with part of speech tags, dependency trees, and other
properties.

methods.name: analyzeSentiment
methods.desc: Analyzes the sentiment of the provided text.

methods.name: annotateText
methods.desc:
A convenience method that provides all the features that analyzeSentiment,
analyzeEntities, and analyzeSyntax provide in one call.

methods.name: analyzeEntities
methods.desc:
Finds named entities (currently finds proper names) in the text,
entity types, salience, mentions for each entity, and other properties.
